title: (x) contemporary, fresh and feminine humanist sans - Christiana {Yves}
content:
Trying to identify this font based on these letters. Part of a marketing presentation for a new product and is considered contemporary, fresh and feminine.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080120204534im_/http:/typophile.com/files/font_request.jpg)

 [‹ AdJuggler](http://web.archive.org/web/20080120204534/http:/typophile.com/node/17027 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) grunge script - Porcelain {Tiff} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080120204534/http:/typophile.com/node/17023 "Go to next forum topic")
author: hanneman

comments.content: Sorry. I’m new at this. I posted the font sample.

If you slant Philip Bouwsma’s [’Neuhengen’](http://web.archive.org/web/20080120204534/http:/www.fonthaus.com/products/fonts/view.cfm/sku/MI203304), you get something quite close to this. (Based on the the style of the ’a’, this may be an obliqued version of a Roman font — it’s not usually the way an Italic ’a’ is drawn.)

- Mike Yanega

I thought so — [Gudrun Zapf von Hesse](http://web.archive.org/web/20080120204534/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Gudrun%252BZapf%252Bvon%252BHesse)’s [Christiana](http://web.archive.org/web/20080120204534/http:/www.philsfonts.com/detail.html?sku=BQ90057001P1), released through [Berthold](http://web.archive.org/web/20080120204534/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Berthold). Slanted and extended. The Zapf connection was well spotted, Patricia.
